node.title: Review: Young Concert Artists Is Back, With a Superb Pianist
node.alt: The pianist Zhu Wang made his New York debut with a recital on Thursday at Zankel Hall, presented by Young Concert Artists.
node.description: Zhu Wang played an unusually interesting and adventurous set of pieces at Zankel Hall.
node.content: ["Since its founding in 1961, Young Concert Artists has supported emerging musicians who win its annual competition \u2014 including offering a coveted New York recital. But during the pandemic, these recitals had to go virtual.", "On Thursday the organization became the latest New York institution to resume in-person concerts when Zhu Wang, a 24-year-old pianist from China, gave an impressive recital at Zankel Hall. Wang, making his New York debut, played a demanding 90-minute program without an intermission.", "With an unusually interesting and adventurous set of pieces, Wang proved a thoughtful, sensitive performer. He began with Bach\u2019s arrangement for keyboard of Alessandro Marcello\u2019s Oboe Concerto in D minor; this was Bach\u2019s pragmatic way of getting to know the latest currents in Italian music from the inside. A lithe, flowing first movement leads to a plaintive Adagio, followed by bustling Presto finale. Wang balanced lyrical warmth and crisp clarity.", "He then turned to Schumann\u2019s \u201cHumoreske,\u201d a 30-minute suite in seven movements. Performances of this remarkable piece are relative rarities, perhaps because its constant shifts of mood and flights of fancy can seem baffling. Wang fervently conveyed the rhapsodic sweep and mercurial fervor of the music, while bringing out the inner structure that holds it together. He was especially impressive during episodes of wistful, poetic tenderness.", "He then spoke to the audience about the next work: Zhang Zhao\u2019s \u201cPi Huang (Moments in Beijing Opera),\u201d which he said offered impressions of Chinese opera, which combines music, dance and even martial arts and acrobatics. The short, fantastical piece was alive with trills and tremolos, rustling arpeggios, beguiling tunes and jittery dance segments driven by Bartokian cluster chords.", "Daniel Kellogg, who became president of Young Concert Artists when Susan Wadsworth, its founder, retired in 2019, appeared onstage with Nina Shekhar, the organization\u2019s composer in residence, to introduce her \u201cVocalise.\u201d (Shekhar will have an orchestral work played by the New York Philharmonic in May.)", "The term vocalise refers to a song without words. In this premiere, she adapted that concept to the piano. This ruminative 12-minute score begins and ends with an elegiac melody, inspired by Hindustani musical styles. There are stretches of thick, tart block chords, searching lyrical lines, mysterious washes of sound and delicate strands, brought together compellingly in Wang\u2019s account.", "He ended with Liszt \u2014 choosing not some overtly virtuosic piece, but that composer\u2019s teeming, imaginative \u201cR\u00e9miniscences de Norma,\u201d a fascinating reflection on Bellini\u2019s opera in which its melodies are transformed into piano music, by turns contemplative and exciting.", "Wang played it brilliantly. And Young Concert Artists is back."]
